title: Will ACLED record any civilian fatalities in Tunisia between 15 October 2017 and 31 October 2017?
preds: None so far as of Oct. 29, per ACLED
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
I'm not entirely sure as to what, if anything, is happening in Tunisia at the moment but I'd imagine they report at least one civilian fatality through that time period.

No report on extent of the injuries or updates on current conditions: Oct. 15 report from ALCED: "Unidentified gunmen invaded farmers in the outskirts of Kairouan. They injured some farmers with shots who had to be transported to the hospital."
Actually, I'm going to bump this up a bit.
Revising downward dramatically due to consensus. But there were three of this kind in September, so I'm not sure why consensus is so low.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
In September 3 fatalities of this sort were recorded, suggesting maybe 1 a week is possible.

No news of conflict violence. At all.
Adjusting downward.

Violence has leveled off significantly from ACLED 2016 data.  Either this is the new baseline, or ACLED just isn't recording data from Tunisia anymore.  Given that this is just a two week period of time, I am estimating 5%

He last event of violence against civilians/remote violence in Tunisia occurred on August 19 and 25.  No events of this particular type has occurred any time after that.   There is always the possibility of an event or events of this nature occurring between today and the end of October.  However, the conditional probability of this event is:  .01 < Event < .50.  The conditional probability of event type of protests has a larger value, therefore, P(Protests | violence against civilians )  > .50
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

This one is scary to forecast because nobody has posted any links . Darn, that means I'm going to have to apply elbow grease. Aha! Twitter!  Lemme see... struck gold! Riots over collision between a civilian boat carrying migrants, and a Tunisian naval vessel.  North-Africa Watch ®‏ @NorAfroWatch  1h1 hour ago
#NorAfroWatch Tunisian navy recovers 10 more bodies after boat collision http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFL8N1MQ16A?feedType=RSS&feedName=tunisiaNews … #Tunisia Dateline 10-15-2017 TUNIS, Oct 15 (Reuters) - Tunisia’s navy said on Sunday it recovered 10 more bodies of Tunisian migrants who drowned when their boat sank last week in a collision with a navy vessel off the country’s coast, bringing the death toll from the incident to 18. Last Monday, the navy recovered eight bodies after the collision with the Tunisian navy boat 54 km (33 miles) off the southern coast, while 38 were rescued. According to testimony from survivors, there were between 70 and 80 people on board, the International Organization for Migration has said. The incident has caused anger in Tunisia. The families of some migrants who drowned protested in two towns. In the southern town of Kebili, protesters burned a local government center this week. The number of illegal migrants trying to reach Italy by boat has shot up in recent weeks as unemployed youth seek to escape poverty. (Reporting by Tarek Amara; Editing by Peter Cooney) -- http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL8N1MQ16A?feedType=RSS&feedName=tunisiaNews Ala Oueslati‏ @Alaoueslat  Oct 8

2017: 7 incidents in 9 months: 77.7% / 2 approx. 38.9%
2015 and 2016: 18 incidents in 24 months: 75% / 2 approx. 37.5%
They have riots/protests every day, violence and civilian fatalities are possible

It's possible, however Tunisia has very few civilian casualties generally. There were three incidents in September but they all seem more like random noise than a pattern of violence against civilians.
